abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory. Key lessons learned included: An
            institutionalized system of close collaboration with other
            projects, agencies, and nongovernmental organizations yields
            a much greater impact than would be possible with a standard
            project. Farmers desire to assume responsibility for
            activities that were formerly carried out by extension
            services. To increase the effectiveness of the second phase
            of the National Agricultural Extension Program, which would
            require an increased role for farmers and farmers
            organizations in both decisionmaking and financing of
            services, decentralization and institutional reform are
            needed. While low cost technologies can easily be introduced
            in a favorable environment, the next level of technologies
            requires that priority needs--like access to credit and to
            markets--are addressed at the farm level at the same time
            before these technologies can be adopted. Literacy trainers
            need to be provided incentives in a systematic way in order
            to encourage the most successful ones to stay in the
            villages and continue training new students.

18157127.trustfund: TF023655-REG. SECONDMENT AGR. EXPERT (AF5AG),TF026105-SAHELIAN NATURAL RESOURCE MGT SUPPORT

abstracts.cdata!:
The project represents the first
            four-year timeslice of a long-term national program designed
            to strengthen agricultural, livestock and forestry extension
            with a view to generate increased agricultural production
            and sustained growth of farmers' and herders'
            incomes.  The project builds on experience gained during the
            implementation of the pilot project.  The main elements of
            the program are:  (i) efficient organization of extension
            services, provided with adequate human and physical
            resources, at the farmer, regional and national levels; (ii)
            regular and continuous training of responsible officials at
            each level by means of a system of fortnightly, monthly and
            annual training sessions; (iii) strengthening of the
            linkages between the extension services and the national and
            regional research services; (iv) strengthening of relations
            between the crop farming, livestock and environment
            services; (v) functional literacy and numeracy training both
            for men and women.  Investment will be in:  (a) civil works;
            (b) vehicles and equipment; (c) incremental operating costs;
            (d) on-farm research; (e) training; and (f) short-term
            technical assistance to establish and periodically supervise
            a project accounting and budgeting system.
